Bionics, Lindsey Wagner, Bionics, Wagner, etc.I religiously monitor the prices on a number of DVDs, as they are want to fluctuate, and had the great fortune of catching this title when it had dropped down to $8.  If you can snag yourself a copy the next time it dips down to that price again, consider yourself very fortunate as it's a heck of a deal. reviewText: Going to get all of the seasons for both Bionic Woman and 6-Million Dollar Man (when they are all available). I would have liked to get them as a box set, but the distributor has seen fit to (SLOWLY) release them 1-by-1.The first BW:Season Two Amazon sent had a scratched disc, but Amazon's great return policy had a new one in my hands in about 7 business days. Make sure that when you get a mulitple-disc season of DVDs that you test each disc (I copy them to my hard drive, using DVDFab) so that your warranty/return policy does not run out on you while you aare watching the programs.On with my review...Season two is great, just like the first one. For those of us that grew up in the 70's as a kid, this was as high-tech as things got back then. Personal computers/laptops were just dreams and the rich kids on the block may have had Pong hooked up to their TV. Great writing, great humor, and (as always), Lindsay Wagner was simply beautiful through it all. This set contains all of the episodes of the second season, including a cross-over episode from the 6-Million Dollar Man. Great bonus extras and interviews!
Title: N/A

reviewText: THE BIONIC WOMAN SEASON 2 DVD SET was marred with production problems and so it's hard for me to give it any higher than 4-stars. Although Universal did offer buyers a replacement disc (after fans created an uproar on the internet and pointed out that there were in fact clean audio tapes in existence for the particular episode) if you sent in the old one, there are still some slight audio issues on other episodes. The audio problems aren't really bad enough to interfere with viewing pleasure, but they are noticeable. Thankfully, they only exist on a few episodes and only in a couple of spots, never running for the entire length of the show.On episode #3 on DVD 5, "The Night Demon," the audio was muffled for about 8-minutes, not so bad that you couldn't hear what was being said, but it's noticeable. Other reviewers pointed out that there's some muffled audio on "Doomsday Is Tomorrow," I couldn't tell, but maybe on repeat viewings.The episode in question where the audio was really bad was on "Deadly Ringer," but I sent in for the replacement before I watched it, thanks to the heads up I got from other Amazon reviewers, so I don't know how bad the audio was and won't comment on it here. Universal's first response was to claim that this was the only version that it had and therefore could not be helped, but after many fans of the show pointed out that this was not the case, the studio went in and corrected the audio, repressed the DVD, and offered buyers a replacement. I'm sure fans wouldn't have been so upset if there hadn't been a clean audio version in existence, such as the UK PAL DVDs or the episodes that were available on HULU, but there you have it. Also, there was never any indication that this was a less than stellar release when buying the set, so buyers had no idea of what they were getting. At least Universal stepped up to try and fix it. Picture quality is fine, however.Anyway, because of those issues I gave this DVD set a very generous 4-stars.*****  EXTRAS  ******* Commentaries creator/director/writer Kenneth Johnson and actress Lindsay Wagner on some episodes* "Six Million Dollar Man" crossover episodes* Photo gallery* "Bionic Blast" -- 11:30-minute featuretteThis is a fun featurette that shows many present day interviews with directors Kenneth Johnson, Alan J. Levi, stunt woman Rita Egleston, Wagner stunt double Inge Rosenberg, stunt coordinator Vince Deadrick, Jr., actors Richard Anderson "Oscar Goldman," Martin E. Brooks "Rudy Wells," and  Robbie Rist "Andrew" (student from season 1). This featurette also shows the toys and merchandise that went along with the series like dolls and lunch boxes.Anyway, despite the shoddy DVD production of the BIONIC WOMAN SEASON 2, the series itself is still fun to watch and I am constantly amazed at the show's high quality production value.I don't know if Universal has pulled the original run of the DVD set with the bad audio on DVD #4, so I can't comment on that, but if you do have audio issues on "Deadly Ringer," episode #3 on DVD 4, look at the forum below to get a replacement DVD.
summary: The Series Gets *5 Stars* But DVD Production Is Marginal!

reviewText: I got the replacement disc for the episode that was poor. What an improvement. The second season, like the first, was better than the PAL version released a few years back. I had both because I needed to see something that was bothering me about the episode "Doomsday is Tomorrow" I remember seeing it a long time ago as a double length telefilm, even though it aired, at least in syndication as 2 parts. I checked the episode guide and it did air in 2 parts but I was sure I saw it as a 2 hour version. I watched the opening credits of part 1 and 2 and they were nearly identical (except of course the Part II under the title in part 2, but I notices that about 1/2 way through the production credits, they stopped and thus I can see where and how at some point it was aired as a 2 parter, as an editor, I can see how they were able to create the double length version without continuity issues. This was done once before in SMDM as The Bionic Woman was aired as a 2 part episode, but in the UK and on VHS video back in the 90s, it was presented as a double length episode (The 2nd season SMDM also included the 2 hour version)
summary: Corrected version much better/Mystery of 2 part episode...

reviewText: What a great story line.  Jamie & Steve vs Fembots.  This along with Day of the Robot and the Seven Million Dollar man episodes made SMDM/BW my favorite shows growing up, but this was the best.  I remember thinking 'no way' when from her bedside Jamie, uttered, 'Steve, they're stronger than bionics'.  For the first time I thought that our heroes might not be able to pull it out.  Perfect balance of action and tension with Oscar's predicament.  John Houseman was the perfect actor to play Dr. Franklin.  He was outstanding in this role.  Robots and aliens (hello Sasquatch) was the sweet spot for the these two series and 'Kill Oscar' is the best of the best.
summary: Kill Oscar trilogy is a high point in the series

reviewText: Season two continues with Jaime Sommers, the world's first bionic woman, finding comfort in her bionic abilities and confidence in her position as an OSI Agent and learning to cope with her personal life when not answering to the horn of Uncle Sam.  The adventures keep getting better with new challenges and more special guest appearances by Steven Austin.  Season two opens up with the conclusion of The Return of Bigfoot part 1 where, a near fatally wounded Steve is in a hospital bed after battling the Sasquatch, Steve entrusts Jaime to locate Shallon, the creator of the Sasquatch, and her alien colony whom have lived secretly in the San Angelo Mountains for hundreds of years, hoping to find Neotraxin, a wonder drug able to cure many diseases.  Jaime finds herself face to face with the Sasquatch in an epic encounter.  Jaime learns that the colony also needs help as many of the colonists, including Shallon, are dying from radiation poisoning caused uncontrollably by the Sasquatch who is not under the control of Nedlick (played by John Saxxon)and a renegade of rebels.  Actress Sandy Duncan and Stephanie Powers guest star.Season two also showcases the world's first 3-parter episode, Kill Oscar starring the legendary John Houseman as Dr. Franklin, former employee of the OSI and creator of the deadliest machines ever to encounter the Bionic Woman...the Fembots with guest appearances by Colonel Steve Austin and Peggy Callahan played by Jennifer Darling.  Actress Lindsay Wagner evolved her character, making Jaime more human than machine protecting and saving the world again and again while still finding time for her personal life as a school teacher and a daughter to Jim and Helen Elgin.  Her passion and dedication for her role, along with her extraordinary portrayal for the second time as Lisa Galloway in Deadly Ringer, earned Lindsay Wagner her Emmy Award in a Prime Time television show this season.  This is definitely not a season to miss and a MUST HAVE for anyone's bionic collection!

reviewText: This is the dvd set of one of my favorite series of the 1970s, the second season of The Bionic Woman.  Like the first (and third) the wonderful Lindsay Wagner takes basically a comic book character and turns her into a real human being.  Thats the main reason this series is so good and still holds up.  (I'm so glad the lame remake attempt of a few years ago failed so miserably.)  Among the notable episodes this season are the croosovers with The Six Million Dollar Man: the well-remembered "Return of Bigfoot" and the excellent 3 part crossover "Kill Oscar."  There are several audio commentaries by Lindsay Wagner and a featurette "Bionic Blast."Despite being a top 20 show its second season, for some reason, ABC cancelled it.  It was quickly picked up by NBC where it lasted one more season before NBC cancelled it (along with most of their schedule.)  Sadly the change in networks ended any more crossovers with The Six Million Dollar Man.  I have always preferred this series to its brother series primarily because Lindsay's Jaime Sommers was so much more interesting than Lee Majors' Colonel Steve Austin.  For some reason this series lasted only half as long as the other: The Bionic Woman's 2 1/2 seasons to Six Million Dollar Man's 5.Anyway, I look forward to the upcoming release of season 3.
summary: The Second Great Season of The Bionic Woman

reviewText: As a child, I watched both The Six Million Dollar Man and its spinoff, The Bionic Woman.  But quickly became more enthusiastic about the latter.  While I was entertained by Steve Austin's derring-do, I cared about Jaime Sommers.Much of the success of The Bionic Woman must be credited to Lindsay Wagner. She brings a combination of charm and intelligence unseen on television since Elizabeth Montgomery's turn in Bewitched - adding hints of sadness and vulnerability. Richard Anderson, brings a fatherly quality to Oscar Goldman - a contrast with his more hard-nosed portrayal in The Six Million Dollar Man. These qualities were utterly lacking in the unmemorable and mercifully short lived 2007 remake.Watching The Bionic Woman after all these years brought back many memories - not all of them pleasant:  I distinctly recall how frightening the unmasked Fembots were to this little boy when first watching the show.  What I missed were the subtle clues that the imposters were not "real", including a slight alteration of the voice and an overly smooth, made up appearance.There is some "insider" humor here that went over my head when I as a child:  Jamie describes one address (on Vermont Avenue NW) as being in a "seedy" part of Washington, DC when in fact  it's one of the more expensive parts of the city and within a three minute walk of the White House.There seems to have been a slight change in the writing between Seasons One and Two.  The first season was focused on establishing and developing the Jaime character.  The second season was straight out action adventure with occasional turns to camp humor and showing skin.  Then there was the recycling of plot elements such as the Return of Bigfoot episode.An array of distinguished guest stars can be seen in Season Two, from John Houseman to Vincent Price (Houseman vigorously chews the scenery during his turn) . The visual style is in keeping with the Universal Television look of the 1970s: simple camera setups, with establishing shots transitioning to two-shots and close-ups, and very little camera movement beyond the occasional pan or zoom. After the hand-held camera style of today's series, this simplicity is a welcome relief.The film elements look reasonably clean - light grain and scratches are visible at times. During the slow motion effects sequences, there is some jumpiness in the image, which I don't remember seeing during the original airing (but that was a long time ago and TV screens were a lot smaller then). One consistent problem is that the fade outs before commercial breaks seem to have been altered, so there is a distracting cut-off effect. Some damaged elements seem to have been covered by using freeze frames.  The sound is two channel mono, the dialogue volume inexplicably drops for the first ten minutes of "Deadly Ringer", and several episodes are seriously lacking in high-end frequency response.  Also, the intro for part 1 of Kill Oscar uses alternate music.The bonus features include a documentary, episode commentary with creator Kenneth Johnson and Lindsay Wagner, and a photo gallery.I understand that the audio problems have been corrected and replacement discs issued.  But the defective version should never have been released in the first place.  So, I am demoting this set to 4 stars. I look forward to the release of Season Three with Maximillion - the bionic dog - and hopefully the reunion movies.

reviewText: I was around six or seven years old during the mid-1970s, and I still recall being struck with an epiphany. Thanks to Lindsay Wagner and Lynda Carter, I realized that girls weren't totally icky. I am so very glad to own entire seasons of WONDER WOMAN and THE BIONIC WOMAN. Me, I consider THE BIONIC WOMAN Season 2 to be the best of that franchise. I think this was the season that won her an Emmy for 1977's Best Actress in a Dramatic Role. And while WONDER WOMAN limited Lynda Carter to portraying a fairly one-dimensional character, THE BIONIC WOMAN presented Lindsay Wagner with plenty of chances to bust out her acting chops. And Lindsay had range, and that certain graceful way about her. Even as a six year old boy, I was smitten.Some of my favorite episodes take place in Season 2. We get the classic crossover episodes with THE SIX MILLION DOLLAR MAN: "The Return of Bigfoot" and the absolutely awesome "Kill Oscar." In "In This Corner, Jaime Sommer," we eyeball Jaime in her Pocahantas-type costume as she infiltrates a shady lady wrestler club. We even hear her talk wrestling smack during a television interview. "Road to Nashville" showcases Lindsay's singing a country song ("Good To Be Alive in the Country") as she tries to locate a vanished OSI agent. "Black Magic" guest-stars Vincent Price as Jaime is deployed to a remote island and gets caught up in a treasure hunt. The fabulous two-part "Deadly Ringer" features the return of Jamie's doppelganger, Lisa Galloway, who has broken out of prison. Jaime, drugged and mistaken for Lisa, gets thrown in the hoosegow. Lindsay Wagner's riveting performance in this two-parter is said to be what won her the Best Actress Emmy that year.Ultimately, "Kill Oscar" is what propels this season over the top for me, even though "The Return of Bigfoot" with its big space alien sci-fi themes is also up there. Anyway, K.I.T.T. had K.A.R.R. The shipwrecked crew had Gilligan. Jamie Sommers had the Fembots. I remember watching the three-part "Kill Oscar" as a kid and being scared silly by the creepy, creepy robot women, and that fear was stoked higher when even Jaime's vaunted bionic strength barely had her holding her own. And then how could you not love her teaming up with Colonel Steve Austin? Lee Majors and Lindsay Wagner together ignited some serious sparks. And damn Jaime's amnesia anyway.Bonus features: "Bionic Blast" - cast & crew reflect about the show's popularity and impact on pop culture and reminisce about stuff like the Fembots and the action figures; audio commentaries on 4 episodes: "Road to Nashville" and "Biofeedback" (with Lindsay Wagner), "Doomsday is Tomorrow, Parts 1 & 2" (with show creator Kenneth Johnson); and a photo gallery.
summary: Season 2 - wrestling Sasquatch and spooky fembots and singing country songs

reviewText: Since Season two was still on ABC they continued to do the crossovers with Six Million Dollar Man which enhanced both shows.  I loved seeing Steve and Jaime team up in Return of Bigfoot, and Kill Oscar.  Also I loved when Lindsay sang Living in the Country in Road to Nashville.  She did a much better job on that one than the song she sang in Season one's episode Bionic Beauty.  Who can forget Feelings.  She sounded like a wailing cat stuck in the mud when she hit the high notes. Anyway I highly recommend Season two to all fans.  Since I have my own copies of Bionic Woman I only purchased Season one because I had a few episode missing from that season. It's great to see my two favorite shows from the 70's finally out on DVD for everyone to enjoy.  Both Six Million Dollar Man and Bionic Woman were easily the best shows of the seventies for me and I'm sure for a lot of people who have been waiting years to see them again.
summary: Season 2 as good as the First

reviewText: This delightfully campy 2nd season episode features guest stars Abe Vigoda, Julie Newmar, William Windom, and a hilarious Vincent Price (in a fun dual role).  The guest stars portray ghoulish heirs assembled at their decrepit family manor on a secluded Louisiana bayous island for a videotaped will reading.  Sent by boss Oscar Goldman (Richard Anderson), an undercover Jaime Sommers (Lindsay Wagner) poses as the family's gypsy niece to retrieve a missing secret formula.  As Jaime quickly discovers, this greedy clan out-creeps "The Addams Family," as each is evidently willing to kill for a fortune.  Then, there is the "monster" stalking the guests -- a nicely-played twist on an old cliché awaits.Great chuckles involve dropped pots overhead "welcoming" unsuspecting new arrivals ... and the heirs taking their best shots breaking into the "burglar-proof" safe.  Better yet, I like how the heirs agree upon "ground rules" for searching Carstairs Manor for the hidden family fortune ... and then each heir quickly ignores those "rules."  Their subsequent treasure hunt (with the prize guaranteed to the clan's "smartest" member) inevitably takes some ominous turns.  Suffice to say, Lindsay Wagner's performance is spot-on spoofing the kind of macabre horror-mystery films that Vincent Price is legendary for.No blood, G-rated violence - great, amusing fun for adults and kids alike.Rating: 5/5 stars.  It's every heir for themselves!
summary: "The Bionic Woman" Meets Vincent Price & a Family of Ghouls in "Black Magic"

reviewText: Let me start first by saying that Lindsay Wagner, Richard Anderson, and creator/producer Kenneth Johnson deserve 10 out of 5 stars for their efforts on this series. The low rating is for the quality of the DVD set itself.The lack of quality control is inexcusable regarding the audio and the failed remastering attempt of the Return of Bigfoot Part 1--evident in all the dust and speckles in the picture.  It is quite clear that Universal did not care about quality control here.  Why, for example, didn't they tell us on the ORIGINAL PRESSINGS that there were known audio problems?  Someone had to have known what the audio was going to sound like!  They didn't bother to bring  up any issues until people started to complain.  I think a disclaimer on the box would have been appropriate in the beginning--definitely!  Multitudes of fans are not buying that this is the best that can be had, as they could have easily extracted audio from other sources.  The excuse that the passage of time may have caused this is questionable since the first season had even OLDER MASTER COPIES, stored in the same location one can only assume, and they had NO problems to speak of.The single most egregious blunder on this set is that the most serious audio problem occurs on the episode for which Lindsay Wagner won her Emmy.  I am sorry, Lindsay, that your fans won't be able to hear what you're even saying during the first 10 minutes.UPDATE:  Universal is offering a remastered replacement Disc 4.  Contact Universal Home Entertainment for details.  FAITH IN THE STUDIO MAY BE RESTORED AFTER ALL...
summary: Adding to the list of the disappointed....BUT WAIT, THERE'S HOPE..REPLACEMENT DISC PROGRAM UNDERWAY AT UNIVERSAL!!!!!!

reviewText: The transfers are beautiful and immaculately crisp. You will enjoy watching the episodes repeatedly. Each episode is in it's original broadcast form and Lindsay Wagner has never looked better.You will need a region 2 dvd player to view this and "Bionic Woman"-Season 2. There is one extra which is a brief montage of other available tv series through Universal Playback. I must warn you before hand though, as there is a creepy anti-piracy advertisement at the end of the last episode of each disc. You'll know what I mean when you see it. reviewText: Whereas I found season 1 to be a bit "corny," but entertaining, season 2 proved to be a let down. Apart from the plot lines and themes, which, for many shows, were of social commentaries of the times, what really bugged me were the poor set designs, filming, and editing. For instance, several shows had repeated chase scenes. In one episode, Jamie falls into some quicksand while fleeing. She escapes and is covered with mud. As her running scenes are edited from shot to shot, she is seen in clean jeans and a shirt, then muddy jeans and a shirt, then back to the mud. In another episode, Jamie has to call into the police station from a street corner police phone. The pole on which the call box is mounted, wobbles. Other times, characters bump into huge boulders, causing the rocks to move a few inches. My favorite is a shot of Jamie in a "padded cell." She inadvertently steps on the drain cover in the middle of the room. The cover spits exactly in half. In a following scene, there is not drain at all. A major disappointment; but, hey, the comic relief is often better than some of the new network stuff that airs today.

reviewText: I would normally rate a series of this great quality with 5 stars, but there are some problems with the set from the production standpoint (i.e. not amazon's problem, but the manufacturer's).  Most noticeably are the sound drop outs in two places in the episodes Deadly Ringer on Disk 4 which lasts 5 minutes, and  briefly on one episode on Disk 5 as well. I turned on the subtitles to find out what was said which worked well. If you look at the whole set as a whole, the big picture it's worth it to get this season. I just think in today's digital technology, they could have done better with the sound problems and looked at other sources for the missed intros. Apparently the Region 2 release has no problems.  I am enjoying the Six Million Dollar Man episodes put out by Time Life and The Bionic Women episodes complement those quite well.Putting all the flaws aside, I would say that this is a great season and series, and the quality is good overall.  Lindsay Wagner shines and it's wonderful that they included all the cross-over episodes. It's refreshing that a series offers compassion and second chances even for some of the misguided criminals, with the wonderful message that there's hope for all. Happy endings are the norm in this series. I'd recommend it, but keep in mind that it's not perfect.Editing to say that the company set me a replacement disk for the production flaw.
summary: Great Series, but DVD's Contain Flaws
Title: N/A

reviewText: I won't provide spoilers with this review. I love this series (and The Six Million Dollar Man  too). Obviously the Bionic Woman is directed at the female viewer. This did not distract the writers from making good stories.That said, we have to remember the decade it came from; namely male dominance and sexist attitudes still prevailed "over the top" then it should have in the series. Overall it still was far, far better then the attempted remake a few years ago.One of the main items they did do wrong was having an episode for The Six Million Dollar Man and cross it over into the Bionic Woman. This does become annoying.Lindsay Wagner plays a very good role, and makes it her own in every detail. During the series she did have some health issues, but as a real trooper she continued on with the series. You may note this as you view the episodes, if you are the type to pay attention to details.As far as the story-line, bionic implants working? She is more than a cyborg then let us say, the Terminator! They push the envelope farther even by today's understanding of such technology but not like those more modern movies and series do. She has warm flesh and blood that the writers take advantage of in many stories and adds greatly to the viewers enjoyment.The fictional government office known as OSI? It works, if you do not look too close. And the head of OSI acts more like an Uncle, than a government boss is just one glaring (not reality) of the series.I recommend streaming an episode, such as episode seven of season one: Bionic Beauty Jaime enters a beauty contest in order to uncover an espionage operation that is endangering American security plans. Namely because, if you don't watch Six Million Dollar Man story which leads up to the Bionic Woman, that first episode won't make much sense.Lastly, and purely personal. Lindsay Wagner was my first teen crush. I fought for her against another pin-up of the seventies. So, in this sense I may still have a bit of prejudice...perhaps?

reviewText: What else can be better than The Bionic Woman Season 1?Oh, but of course, it certainly would have to be The Bionic Woman; Season 2!!Coming off a very inpressive and convincing first season of The Bionic Woman, Lindsay Wagner returns for more high-octane high-speed supercharged action & adventure in Season 2, which was launched as part of the new fall line-up on September 22, 1976!! It contains all 22 explosive episodes of that season. Season 2 differs from Season 1, mainly because Season 1 features only 13 episodes, having debuted midseason as a replacement for a departing hour-long show in that timeslot.Perhaps the most notable thing about Season 2 is that there are at least 2 crossover episodes of The Six Million Dollar Man, featuring Lee Majors as Colonel Steve Austun (The Return of Bigfoot Pts. 1 & 2 and Kill Oscar Pts. 1, 2 & 3), so that you don't miss a thing!! Wagner & Majors appeared in some of the episodes of both shows, working together and showing off their impressive acting talents!Plus there are a whole slew of a bonus featurette; "Bionic Blast" where Lindsay Wagner & the show's producer; Kenneth Johnson discuss the merchandising of the series, how the stunts were performed and who their favorite villans were. Also a gag reel and photo gallery are included.But just like fine wine, The Bionic Woman continues to get even better with age!!! This ground-breaking series was the result of it being brought back to life on prime-time TV by popular demand of the TV viewers who watched pro tennis player / school teacher Jamie Sommers die on the operating table in one of the episodes of The Six Million Dollar Man. That was going to be the last viewers would see of Jamie. CBS had responded immensely by having reserected the character from death, giving Lindsay her own show!! It was just as good to see a female cyborg do just about everything her very convincing counterpart male cyborg can do!!Battling thugs and throwing them 30 feet in the air, dispaching the bad guys, running in excess of 60mph, bending and twisting steel with her bare right hand, as well as kicking heavy steel doors right off their hinges and leaping to the tops of buildings with the greatest of ease are nothing to Jamie Sommers and seems like an everyday part of her assignments as an OSI special agent!! She is all business, as she handles all of her assignments given to her by her boss; Oscar Goldmen!!Season 2 featured a whole slew of famous guest stars, including Stephenie Powers (who was also The Girl From U.N.C.L.E.), Sandy Duncan, John Saxon (Enter the Dragon), Vincent Price and Julie Newmar. The set feature five discs with English subtitles and English mono sound (but I have an external stero speaker for the TV in the bedroom which gives enhanced stereo sound and a home theater system for the TV in the living room).I especially like the sound effects on the show - the electronic sound heard when Jamie starts to run, is running, about to punch someone's light out and the loud echoing thud when she hits someone or kicks open a steel door!!! Slow motion is added so that you can really see her in action when she does something bionic!!Wagner also impressively won her much-deserved Emmy Award as Outstanding Actress in a Drama Series-the 2-part episode of Deadly Ringer, beating out several other famous female stars in the same cetegory for their other drama series!!Here are the episodes in order as they appear on the discs;Disc 1;1. The Return of Biigfoot Pt. 12. The Return of Biggfoot Pt 2.3. In This Corner, Jamie Sommers.4. Assault on the Princess.Disc 2.5. Road to Nashville.6. Kill Oscar Pt. 1.7. Kill Oscar Pt. 2.8. Kill Oscar Pt. 3.10. Black Magic.Disc 3.11. Sister Jamie.12. The Vega Influence.13. Jamie's Shield Pt. 1.14. Jamie's Shield Pt. 2.15. Biofeedback.Disc 4.16. Doomsday is Tomorrow Pt. 1.17. Doomsday is Tomorrow Pt. 2.18. Deadly Ringer Pt. 1.19. Deadly Ringer Pt. 2.20. Jamie And The King.Disc 5.21. Beyond the Call.22. The DeJon Caper.23. The Night Demon.24. Iron Ships And Dead Men.25. Once a Thief.It appears as though the episodes total 25, but some of them are two-part episodes, counting as one whole episode.CAUTION / UPDATE;Universal, greatly known for its whole slew of 1950's classic sci-fi movies such as The Deadly Mantis,Tarantula, The Mole People and others, as well as tons of TV shows, has brilliently worked with producers Kenneth Johnson and Harve Bennett to put together this magnificent story of a pro tennis player / school teacher who gets a top-secret surgery after a tragic sky diving accident to transform her into a miracle of modern technology!!Universal has posted an advisory, saying that some of the episodes , especially the 2-part one - Deadly Ringer, may have poor audio quality due to the fact that Universal couldn't find a proper master tape for that particular episode. But remember that this show was in production over 30 years ago, so it retains most of it's original orgins, even though Universal says from time to time that the episodes of the show were digitally remastered onto the DVD's.After the release of the 40-DVD all-100-episode package of The Six Million Doallar Man, it was also later decided that all three seasons of The Bionic Woman should also be released on DVD as well!!But in any case, the episodes should, for the most part, remain intact with no edited or censored scenes.Enjoy!!~Daquan13.
summary: The Bionic Woman; Season 2!! More Explosive Action & Adventure than in Season One!!!!

reviewText: I started watching this show when it first debuted in 1977 or 1978.  I don't remember.  I was a young child then and all I remember is that I wanted to be just like Jaime. reviewText: Films and television shows from the 70's are often a hit or miss. Viewers seeking the fond feelings of nostalgia may instead find themselves suffering through fits of laughter over the corniness and camp factor of the show. But this is NOT the case with "The Bionic Woman". It was surprisingly well-written and well acted. It was also interesting how real (and future) innovations in science and technology were used as the basis of the series. Lindsay Wagner of course is the real standout. She portrays Jamie Sommers with just the right balance of vulnerability and strength.  The show holds up remarkable well after all these years.

reviewText: The "Black Magic" episode from "The Bionic Woman" was one I remembered fondly for having Vincent Price playing both a typical murderous businessman and his elderly brother who leaves a fortune to whoever is "smart enough". Upon watching it again, I realized one of my favorite character actors (the mighty William Windom) played the conniving executor of the will. Overall, a charming trip down memory lane and a great example of how Price could adjust to almost any theatrical endeavor he participated in.

reviewText: I purchased both seasons and I was prepared for the "disk" in question to be defective, but it wasn't. The audio was perfectly fine. I skimmed through and everything seemed great! Great audio/video quality. But I must admit I didn't purchase this from Amazon, but another site.*******UPDATE********Not sure if by now it's worth mentioning since MUCH time has passed, but I am going to LIST the other flaws (NOT COUNTING the DEADLY RINGER PART 1 nine minute flaw), since that has been addressed and now those episodes are perfect and beautiful.Here are the things I've noticed that are wrong in season two:A) Doomsday is Tomorrow Part II about 25 minutes into the show (give or take) where Jaime is talking to the remote computer trying to repair her leg, suddenly the audio goes from crystal clear to more muffled for the rest of the episode. Certainly watchable, but the audio is noticeably NOT as clear as up until that point.B)The Night Demon from the time Jaime is talking to the creepy clerk outside the gas station until she is in the lab speaking with the guy developing the photos, the audio is very muffled with background sounds enhanced. As she is talking to the guy in the lab, suddenly the audio becomes crystal clear for the rest of the episode.C)Kill Oscar Part I From the very beginning until just after the opening credits and Jaime is speaking with Callahan before going into the lab to speak with rudy, suddenly then, the audio becomes crystal clearD) Road to Nashville - the opening credits are VERY muffled, but the entire episode is perfect....What's up with that?I don't think I've missed anything else. But I do notice that some opening intro's are not nearly as crystal clear (sound wise) as other intros, yet the episodes with those (not so clear) intros are fine. Strange!You can REALLY tell in the opening sequence of Deadly Ringer that it was fixed, because that opening couldn't possibly be any better sounding. I think that has the best opening title sequence (sound wise) of the entire season now that it was fixed.All in all, these flaws I mentioned above are not NEARLY as bad as Deadly Ringer (first nine minutes) from what what I've read. You can still enjoy these episodes and try your best to overlook these unnecessary flaws like I did - but it just ANNOYS me that the PAL versions have all crystal clear audio and are flawless. I mean, this is an AMERICAN Show, yet the Europeans get better material than we do. It's very easy for people to buy the PAL version and a region free DVD player - HOWEVER, people who have a good ear will notice a 4% increase in speed and it's hard for me to tolerate that. As far as picture quality - No complaints. Picture is very good, especially with an upconverting blu ray player : DPS - I have the season two PAL UK version and I can say the audio is FINE on all episodes, but the video quality doesn't look NEARLY as good to me as the NTSC version here.Hope this helps.I'm not huge DVD collector, but I just absolutely LOVED this show. I liked SMDM too, but Lindsay's acting was better than Lee Majors IMO.
summary: Bionic Woman Season 2~ I will list the defects in this set now that I have watched them all!

reviewText: I like this show, but it's very obvious that it's not very real.  For Example, when Jamie Summers goes to leap / jump over something, or just jump stright up, it looks as if she going to be Climbing Up a Ladder, where as with the Six Million Dollar Man, Steve goes Running and then he Jumps to go over something OR Jumping Straight Up.  Then she get a job working as a teacher @ a Milatry Base School; Milatary Bases DON'T have Elamentry / Junior High School Classes for Young Students; it's Strictly for the Milatary Staff ONLY!  If she's a teacher, then why is she always going out on Different Mission's and how come she Doesn't get FIRED for NOT going to Work as a Teacher?  Who's supposed to be teaching her class of student's?  What is she on, a Perminent Paid Vacation OR on Perminent Sick Leave?

Title: N/A

reviewText: I grew up on the Six Million Dollar Man and the Bionic Woman and watched both religiously during their original runs.  The thing about the Bionic Woman is that many of the actual stories I felt were inferior to the SMD Shows and in fact, some of the stories on BW were remakes of a sort from the SMD Series.However, Lindsay Wagner made this show a hit in its own right and simply carried it through a very respectable run for those times.  Her character of Jaimie Sommers is just as meaningful as the Lee Majors, Steve Austin character and of course, the show benefited from basically the same ensemble cast (Oscar Goldman, Rudy Wells and more screen time for Callahan, Oscar's secretary)The highlight of Season II though is the 3-Part "Kill Oscar" Story with John Houseman as the villain (thus reuniting him with Lindsay Wagner from "The Paper Chase" Movie a few years earlier.  For these three episodes alone, the 2nd year is made memorable and of course, Lee Majors also appears in this "crossover" episode although Jaime is clearly the star of this one.  The 3-Parter holds up amongst the best of the BW and SMD combined Series Episodes and no doubt this was the reason to bring the "Fembots" back in Year 3 in a 2-Part Story which was also enjoyable.The other notable "Crossover" Episode is the "Bigfoot" Sequel begun in the SMD.  This one is OK with 70's stalwarts Sandy Duncan and John Saxon in guest roles but the Stefanie Powers Role, so prominent in the original episode, is drastically reduced in terms of screen-time and Ted Cassidy ("Lurch" of "The Addams Family) replaced Andre the Giant as "Bigfoot" due to his unavailability to return to the role. Overall, this one pales to the original episode although Lee Majors does again appear in this one and thus, a "crossover" episode.There are some other good episodes with excellent guest stars such as "Black Magic" with the venerable Vincent Price and on the whole, a good season of bionics but not spectacular.  Again though, Lindsay Wagner is simply terrific and carries the project admirably!
summary: Kill Oscar Is the Gem here!

reviewText: This one season is, in my opinion, the best ever! My DVD set is obviously the fixed version. I remember consumers were complaining about the episode "Deadly Ringer Part 1" with the muffled audio in the first 9:33 minutes. I noticed no such problem with my copy. As I write this, I am watching that particular episode. No problems at all. I enjoyed the Bigfoot episodes and the three part "Kill Oscar" episodes as well. I remember these from when they first aired back in the 70s. Brings back memories!! I did notice that the intro on one episode did have a muffled sound. I think it was the second part of the Bigfoot episodes. It wasn't that distracting because as soon as the actual show began, the sound was perfect! I can't complain. The episode "Black Magic" was awesome because I have always been a Vincent Price fan. Mr. Price and Lindsey Wagner showed great chemistry in that episode. To put it plain, if you love this show, get this DVD!! You won't regret it!
summary: The Best Bionic Woman Season Ever!!

reviewText: I haven't seen this series, since, ahem, middle school. I remember that our family used to watch this and "The Bionic Man" all of the time. The surprising thing about going back to this series is that it is very well-acted, particularly by Ms. Wagner. The story lines are also (mostly) plausible with some of them being more intimate and personal for the various characters. Season Two expanded on Season One with more special effects and science-based story lines. Who can forget the fembots? Pity the poor actresses that had to wear those ungainly robotic heads AND have fighting sequences. Though the special effects may seem a bit dated by today's standards, but, they hold up well, again, largely due to the acting chops of Ms. Wagner. This was, and is, a very entertaining series that has a heart and is great fun to watch. The funny thing is that I seem to remember those 70's fashions looking much more horrible than they do in this series. Either it is the attractiveness of Ms. Wagner or they simply just dressed her better.
summary: Never boring and very well acted.

reviewText: I came here to write exactly what Mr. Bangs conveyed so perfectly in his review.  This is the best season of "The Bionic Woman," but Universal has made it unwatchable (and inaudible).  Never before have I seen a release so poorly put-together.  Mr. Bangs gave this one star, and I whole-heartedly agree.  We're not dissatisfied with Lindsay Wagner or the series itself, but Universal for releasing such a horrible transfer.  Fix it, Universal!  Seriously.

reviewText: This 1976-77 Season about a retired pro-tennis player now schoolteacher(Lindsay Wagner)who nearly dies in a skydiving accident and gets rescued by her superior Oscar Goldman from the OSI and restored by cyborg scientist Dr. Rudy Wells(Martin E. Brooks)with bionic surgical implants similar to Col.Steve Austin's(Lee Majors)on THE SIX MILLION DOLLAR MAN is a definite upgrade from Season 1 since this is where THE BIONIC WOMAN really started hitting its stride.It was also interesting seeing guest stars in this 1976-1977 Season like*Jack Colvin in the "Kill Oscar" episode before his co-starring days as the obsessed overzealous reporter(Jack McGee)on THE INCREDIBLE HULK*Julie Newmar in the "Black Magic" episode after her co-starring days as Catwoman on BATMAN*Ted Cassidy in "The Return of Bigfoot" episode after his co-starring days as Lurch on THE ADAMS FAMILY*Norman Fell in the "In This Corner, Jaime Sommers" episode before his co-starring days as Mr. Roper on THREE'S COMPANY*Stefanie Powers in "The Return of Bigfoot" episode before her co-starring days on HART TO HART*Bill Boyett in the "Once A Thief" episode after his co-starring days as Sgt. MacDonald on ADAM-12*John Houseman in the "Kill Oscar" episode before his co-starring days as the cynical Edward Stratton II on SILVER SPOONS*Charles Cyphers known for his role as Sheriff Brackett in John Carpenter's HALLOWEEN, Dan in THE FOG, and as the Secretary-of-the-state in ESCAPE FROM NEW YORK; guest starring in "The Return of Bigfoot" episode*Abe Vigoda in the "Black Magic" episode during his co-starring days on BARNEY MILLER*Jack Ging in the "Kill Oscar" episode before his co-starring days as the hard-nosed Army nemesis(Gen. Fullbright)on THE A-TEAM*Vincent Price in the "Black Magic" episode after his co-starring days as Egghead on BATMAN*Kathleen Nolan in the "Sister Jaime" episode before her co-starring days as Carol Baldwin on MAGNUM, PI*William Bryant in the "Jaime's Shield" episode before his co-starring days as Colt's director on THE FALL GUY*Granville Van Dusen in the "Biofeedback" episode before his co-starring days on THE YOUNG & THE RESTLESS and ONE LIFE TO LIVE*Don Porter in the "Deadly Ringer" episode after his co-starring days on GIDGET*Eddie Barth in the "Once A Thief" episode before his co-starring days as Rick and AJ's buddy(Myron Fowler)on SIMON & SIMON

reviewText: After the huge sales of "The Bionic Woman-Season 1" on DVD last October now comes word from Universal Studios that "The Bionic Woman-Season 2" arrives in stores on May 17th, 2011. This is the series' first complete season because season one only contained 13 episodes as "The Bionic Woman" was a mid-season replacement on ABC. Season 2 started on network television on September 22, 1976 and contains 22 episodes. The great thing about this boxset (besides the fact that "The Bionic Woman" is available on DVD for fututre generations to enjoy) is that there are two crossover episodes included from "The Six Million Dollar Man" so the viewer can watch the complete full story arch on "The Bionic Woman" box set.There are a slew of bonuses including a new featurette with Lindsay Wagner, Kenneth Johnson, and crew members entitled "Bionic Blast" where they discuss the merchandising of the series, how the stunts were performed, and who their favorite villins were. There are new audio commentaries on select episodes by Lindsay and series creator Johnson. Actress Janice Whitby (who played fembot Katy in the episode "Kill Oscar") has stated she has done some voice over work that will be included as commentary on this set. Finally, there is also a gag reel and photo gallery included."The Bionic Woman" continued to enthrall audiences young and old upon its first network broadcast with season 2 finishing a respectful #14 in the national Nielsen Ratings. This would, however, be the series' final year on ABC as the network canned it citing "The Bionic Woman" was not attracting the kind of young demographic it desired. Season 3 was picked up by rival network NBC in the fall of 1977.Guest-stars in season 2 include Stephanie Powers, Sandy Duncan, John Saxon, Vincent Price, and Julie Newmar. This is a 5 disc set with english subtitles and english mono sound.This was the season Lindsay won her much deserved Emmy as Oustanding Actress in a Drama Series for the two-part episode "Deady Ringer". Her competition that year was Angie Dickinson for "Police Woman", "Michael leaned ("The Waltons"), Sada Thompson for "Family", and Kate Jackson ("Charlie's Angels").UPDATE, July, 28, 2011..."The Bionic Woman-Season 3, The Final Season" comes to DVD on October 4, 2011!!!!The following is a list of episodes included in "The Bionic Woman-Season 2" box set, all 22 shows along with the 1 crossover episode from "The Six Million Dollar Man". Also listed are the airdates.1. "The Return of Bigfoot-Part 1" from "Six Million Dollar Man", Sept. 19, 19762. "The Return of Bigfoot-Part 2, Sept. 22, 19763. "In This Corner, Jamie Summers", Sept. 29, 19764. "Assault on the Princess", Oct. 6, 19765. "Road To Nashville, Oct. 20, 19766. "Kill Oscar-Part 1", Oct. 27, 19767. "Kill Oscar-Part 2" from "Six Million Dollar Man", but released in syndication as a "Bionic Woman" episode, Oct. 31, 19768. "Kill Oscar-Part 3, Nov. 3, 19769. "Black Magic", Nov. 10, 197610. "Sister Jamie", Nov. 24, 197611, "The Vega Influence", Dec. 1, 197612. "Jamie's Shield-Part 1", Dec. 15, 197613. "Jamie's Shield-Part 2", Dec. 22, 197614. "Biofeedback", Jan. 12, 197715. "Doomsday is Tomorrow-Part 1", Jan. 19, 197615. "Doomsday is Tomorrow-Part 2", Jan. 26, 197616. "Deadly Ringer-Part 1", Feb. 2, 197717. "Deadly Ringer-Part 2", Feb. 9, 197718. "Jamie and the King", Feb. 23, 197719. "Beyond the Call", March 9, 197720. "The DeJohn Caper", March 16, 197721. "The Night Demon", March 23, 197722. "Iron Ships and Dead Men", March 30, 197723. "Once a Thief", May 4, 1977UPDATE: JULY 1, 2011: Fans have been complaining (and rightly so) that the episode "Deadly Ringer" has poor audio quality. This was due to the fact that Universal couldn't find a proper master tape for that particular show (remember these episodes are over 30 years old). Now, fans can rejoice in knowing the studio has found another master tape and has corrected the problem. For fans not satisfied with disc 4 that contains "Deadly Ringer" they can contact Universal for a replacement disc by emailing them at USHE.ConsumerRelations@bydeluxe.com or by phoning 888-882-5779.

reviewText: Yes, I know: "not fit for purchase" or some such would be better English.  Still, it's important that anyone reading this review understand that while Universal is to be commended for (finally!) releasing this best season of the timeless classic for which Lindsay Wagner justifiably won an Emmy award, THE CURRENT PRESSING IS UNFIT FOR SALE due to an extended section of barely audible audio at the beginning of the (first part) of the very episode for which she won it: "Deadly Ringer" on Disc Four.This is not an issue with a small batch of discs, but instead something which originated with the studio -- a problem being discussed like crazy on every bionic internet group, and by now something the studio -- whose consumer relations department has issued a statement about it -- is aware of as well.  What Uni Consumer Relations told my fellow fan listserv participant is that they can't do anything about it because these are old shows with less-than-perfect masters!  TVShowsOnDVD is also covering this issue, and it's worth noting that all three seasons are available in English with PERFECT audio tracks in non-US releases which can be imported and enjoyed with the right equipment and know-how, though obviously without the much-anticipated special features of this release, which are very good, and will be most welcome once a new pressing is done with all the audio intact.A few quick words about the program & this season: This is the classic counterpart program to The Six Million Dollar Man, the groundbreaking action/SF series of the '70s based on Martin Caidan's 1972 novel, Cyborg.  For those who don't already know, Six Mil creator Kenneth Johnson decided to create a "Bride of Frankenstein" for Col. Austin at the end of his second season, and a two-part episode introduced fans to Jaime Sommers, former tennis pro-turned middle school teacher, Steve's first heartthrob.  Lindsay Wagner proved so popular in the role that ANOTHER two-part story was hastily written and aired, even though execs at "The Black Tower" (a.k.a. ABC, the program's original network) had insisted that Jaime not live through her first appearance.The huge groundswell these Six Mil episodes created carried Lindsay to the top of the A-list, and ultimately (as I just said above) to an Emmy Award for (I think the wording was) Best Actress in an Action/SF series -- a true cultural benchmark, for a woman had never been the star of a US TV action series before.  In this, The Bionic Woman's second season, the creative team reached what I feel to have been the series' high-water mark as Ms. Wagner worked closely with Johnson and the other writers and directors to bring a truly feminine tenderness to a character which could have been -- as she told me personally a couple years ago -- "The Six Million Dollar Man in a skirt."  In addition to the aforementioned Emmy-winning story arch, this season is also when John Houseman appears in the role of misogonystic former O.S.I. scientist Dr. Franklin, who unleashes his "Fembots -- as beautiful or as deadly as I wish to make them" on Jaime and her loyal viewers!  Other notable guest stars included Vincent Price, Norman Fell, Lew Ayres, Lloyd Bochner and Country star Hoyt Axton.So you see: When Universal re-presses Disc Four, this will be a must-own set for anyone nostalgic for the halcyon childhood some of us were lucky enough to have, in which science, coupled with humanity could still produce everyday heroes -- ones we pretended were our big brother and sister, and still love to this day.  Until then, however, DO NOT BUY THIS SET!!  It's just not worth getting all psyched up for, only to turn on your TV, and...not hear anything at all for nearly ten minutes.Better luck next time, Universal.  thanks for trying, anyway.
summary: Technical Issues Make This Release Unbuyable
